newsitem.title: USA: U.S. copyright firms lose $10.6 billion to pirates.
newsitem.headline: U.S. copyright firms lose $10.6 billion to pirates.

text.p: U.S. computer software and entertainment industries said Tuesday they lost about $10.6 billion last year to copyright piracy in more than 50 countries.

The International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA) asked U.S. trade officials to put three countries -- Greece, Paraguay and Russia -- on a high priority list for possible trade sanctions if they fail to improve copyright protection.
"The magnitude of the global copyright piracy problem demands a decisive response from the U.S. government under our trade laws," IIPA President Eric Smith said in a statement.

The IIPA, which represents a number of U.S. copyright industries including software and entertainment, outlined its recommendations for government action in a filing with the U.S. Trade Representative's Office.

Paraguay accounted for about $117 million in losses last year, up from $44.6 million the year before, the IIPA said. It said Paraguay is a major trans-shipment center for counterfeit goods made in China and Taiwan.
Russia, where copyright protection is non-existent and pirated goods are 70 percent to 90 percent of the market, accounted for more than $1 billion in losses, it said.

IIPA said that U.S. industries, particularly motion picture companies, have been hurt for years by inadequate copyright enforcement in Greece, which accounted for about $127 million in losses last year.

It also asked the U.S. Trade Representative to maintain a watchful eye on China, which agreed last year to take action against copyright pirates after going to the brink of a tit-for-tat trade war with the United States over the issue.
"While the Chinese government has taken laudable aggressive actions to close down CD production lines, much rmains to be done to open this market to creative industries," the group said.
It also said Mexico had failed to live up to intellectual property rights provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
U.S. trade officials have until April 30 to decide which countries they will target for possible trade action for copyright violations.
